sub_title: Global Governance Policy Coordinator at WWF International
summary: After anthropological research and coordination of a large action research project, "Culture and Conservation" in the interior of Indonesian Borneo, I joined WWF Indonesia and the WWF network twenty  years ago. My work has focused on strengthening the recognition of IPs rights especially in protected areas and improving governance and equity in natural resources. My work has also aimed at integrating and strengthening social and development dimensions in conservation initiatives (human rights principles, policies, best practices and indicators) at local, national, regional, and global levels, and building relevant capacity of staff and partners from local to global. Key issues include: social equity and inclusion, good governance of natural assets and shared governance of protected areas, recognition of Indigenous Peoples' rights, supporting ICCAs and territories of life, building networks and empowering civil society, Green Economies, sustainable livelihoods and rural well being; advocacy related to CBD and SDGs.

treasury_media.title: How Indigenous Peoples Practices Can Guide Our Recovery From COVID-19
treasury_media.description: Cristina Eghenter argues that learning from Indigenous Peoples is the best way to repair our broken relationship with nature and secure a healthy future.

treasury_media.title: The woman and the forest 8Th March 2019.jpg
Interview with Cristina Eghenter, WWF-Indonesia
treasury_media.description: We sat down with Cristina Eghenter from WWF-Indonesia and the Heart of Borneo program, to talk about how her focus on governance is a unique, but growing, approach to conservation. What is your role at WWF? My official title at is Deputy Director for Governance and Social Development, which encompasses a synergy of a few distinct, but overlapping and related, roles.

school.name: Centre for South-East Asian Studies, University of Hull, UK

education.field_of_study: economic history anthropology philosophy social science methods

projects.title: Task Force HoB Green Ecotourism
projects.description: The Task Force shall identify and make recommendations for a roadmap to promote, implement and market green, trans-border, and sustainable ecotourism in the interior of Borneo especially in the border area between Indonesia and Malaysia. The Task Force shall identify best practices of community-based ecotourism and make recommendations for common standards in multi-stakeholder ecotourism development and practices in HoB. The Task Force will make recommendations for the design and promotion of Visit HoB 2018 including the launching event. The Task Force shall be solely advisory and shall prepare a presentation for the 11th HoB Trilateral Meeting in North Kalimantan and submit a report to POKJANAS by November 30th, 2017

contributors.headline: Global Governance Policy Coordinator at WWF International

projects.title: Working Group ICCAs Indonesia (WGII)
projects.description: A group of Indonesian NGOs working on Indigenous Peoples rights, forest and environmental governance, documentation of traditional knowledge, equitable access to natural resources, and collaborating to promote documentation and recognition of ICCAs or Indigenous peoples’ territories and areas conserved by indigenous peoples and local communities. WGII is a member of the ICCA Consortium since August 2015.

projects.title: Social Development for Conservation (SD4C), Asia Pacific Regional Network
projects.description: Growing out of earlier initiatives on poverty, equity, indigenous peoples, and regional network experiences (LAN), the Social Development for Conservation (SD4C) team was established in 2009 to address social and development dimensions in conservation, and to build our capacity as a network to effectively and pro-actively engage in these processes. For more effectiveness, regional networks were created starting in 2010. SD4C is a network of WWF social and development experts working in various capacities and in all the regions. SD4C is a truly global and inclusive team, able to capture and broker thinking, learning, and best practices to: Promote better understanding of development dynamics and social issues in regional contexts and emerging economies; Highlight and leverage more expertise from the regions, invest in advocacy capacity and analysis; Facilitate knowledge buidling and dialogues on issues such as social impact and safeguards, sustainable development and right-based approaches; Foster  south‐to‐south learning, initiatives and partnerships at multiple levels to better address development and environmental challenges.

contributors.headline: Global Governance Policy Coordinator at WWF International

projects.title: FORMADAT-The Alliance of the Indigenous Peoples of the Highlands of Borneo
projects.description:
FORMADAT is a trans-border grass-root initiative by communities in Indonesia (East Kalimantan) and Malaysia (Sarawak) that aims to increase awareness and understanding about the communities of the Highlands, maintain cultural traditions, build local capacity, and encourage sustainable development in the Heart of Borneo without risking the degradation of the the quality of the social and natural environment.

Lewi G. Paru, Customary Chief of Krayan Selatan (2006): "FORMADAT is a forum to serve the interests of all of us who live along the order of the Borneo Highlands. This is a good forum. It unites us in one fellowship, one thought, one journey to look after our homeland in the Highlands, our rights..."

contributors.name: Local leaders in Bario-Ba' Kelalan-Long Pasia

projects.title: Green& Fair Products Initiative
projects.description: The Green& Fair Products Initiative of WWF Indonesia is an effort to build stronger rural-urban market links for products that are 'green' (sustainably managed or cultivated or harvested; organic; from use zones of protected areas; etc) and 'fair' (right price, proper labor requirements, direct sales and proceeds go back to communities, community enterprises, fair trade, etc), and support economic empowerment of communities around protected areas and promote sustainable and equitable management of natural resources.

contributors.headline: Global Governance Policy Coordinator at WWF International

projects.title: Community-Based Ecotourism in the Heart of Borneo
projects.description: Pilot projects in community-based ecotourism in areas of the interior of Malinau (Hulu Bahau; Hulu Pujungan) and Nunukan (Krayan Highlands) to promote the areas as ecotourism destinations; support the locals in the development of local packages, short and long-distance treks; help draft community protocols; build the capacity of local men and women as service providers and owners of the project; link with Tour Operators for marketing who share a similar approach to ecotourism and community empowerment.

contributors.headline: Global Governance Policy Coordinator at WWF International

projects.title: WWF Learning and Action Network (LAN) Asia Pacific
projects.description:
The network was born out of the realization that WWF needs to explicitly address issue of equity and good governance for conservation initiatives to be sustainable. Local communities and governments often pay disproportionately high economic and social costs for the existence of a conservation area or conservation initiatives. This is increasingly leading to social conflict and loss of local support for conservation. In order to address these challenges and build a more equitable conservation WWF needs to: 
•	Improve advocacy for policies that can promote equity and sustainability in natural resource management
•	Promote the rights of Indigenous and local communities in land- and seascapes, and ensure conditions of good and fair governance in natural resource management and conservation
•	Promote  equity and social inclusion in the design and implementation of access and benefit sharing schemes to ensure that those most affected by conservation interventions bear the highest costs
•	Improve our ability to demonstrate more systematically linkages between equity, good livelihood and good governance of natural resources.

authors.headline: Global Governance Policy Coordinator at WWF International

profile_positions.description: The Coordinator, Global Governance Policy will support the WWF Network to deepen and build advocacy capacity and coherency on social and governance dimensions of biodiversity policy, sustainable natural resources management and climate mitigation and adaptation. Particular emphasis will be on building enabling global policy and implementation frameworks for human rights based and inclusive approaches to conservation and sustainable development, on securing effective roles for indigenous peoples and local communities as well as women and youth, on restraints on civic space and on policy levers to operationalize the human right to a healthy environment
profile_positions.title: Global Governance Policy Coordinator

profile_positions.description:
Practice Leadership Team members will help shape the Practice Agenda and specifically contribute 
towards the development, implementation, evaluation, and ongoing refinement of the Practice Strategy; scanning and evaluation of trends and opportunities that affect the Practice; Thought leadership on specific topics and facilitation of external relationships at global, thematic or regional level.
profile_positions.title: Governance Practice Leadership Team

profile_positions.description: Ensure the effective mainstreaming of social development, social equity, right-based approach and good governance of natural resources issues in the conservation agenda and priorities of WWF; help build a stronger civil society and develop partnerships with other CS organizations for sustainable development, and engage in collaborations with key stakeholders in Indonesia, Heart of Borneo and in the Asia Pacific region. Ensure timely and appropriate input on social, rights, shared governance  and benefit sharing aspects related to cross-cutting issues (production, consumption, green economies) to enhance economic and social benefits from conservation and development for all, with particular attention to women, Indigenous Peoples, vulnerable and marginalized people. Coordinate network(s) and open communities of practice at regional and global levels (SD4C) focusing on rural well-being, equitable and sustainable food systems, traditional knowledge, and equitable access to natural resources, human rights in conservation; design and implement stronger social development policies, principles and guidelines. Engage in policy discussions and negotiations around MDGs/SDGs, CBD, WPC, ICCAs and rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities. Develop strategies at landscape/island/regional levels to optimize social development perspective and contribute to a more equitable conservation and sustainable development agendas. Develop social impact monitoring indicators and measures for well-being (beyond GDP).
profile_positions.title: Deputy Director Social Development; Indigenous Peoples Governance and Local Food Systems

profile_positions.title: Dr

profile_positions.description:
Civil Society Thematic Lead is a key part of the Borneo Programme Core Team, taking responsibility for ensuring all streams of work related to civil society and rural communities in Borneo are coordinated and work towards the delivery of Pillar 3 of the Borneo Programme Strategic Framework. 
•	Ensure the stewardship of an integrated Civil Society thematic strategy in HoB. The strategy is to empower communities, Indigenous Peoples (e.g., FORMADAT) and civil society for sustainable, green and equitable development in Borneo. 
•	Inititiate, coordinate and provide input on social development and Indigenous Peoples to the Government National Working Group for the HoB Trilateral Initiative as requested and relevant. Develop and implement strategies across the border to enhance the delivery of the Borneo programme, ensure inclusion and participation of vulnerable groups, and represent the program in relevant national and international fora and events.
profile_positions.title: Civil Society Thematic Lead for Borneo Programme (regional)
